stories.text: Yesterday was our school sports day. My best friend, Leo, is a great runner and he wanted to be the **champion** of the 100-meter race. He practiced very hard for weeks, showing great **dedication** to his training. During the race, he was leading, but suddenly he felt a sharp pain in his leg. It was a serious **injury** that made him **collapse** on the track. The schoolâ€™s **medical** team ran to help him immediately. Although he didnâ€™t win a **medal** this time, we were all very proud of him.

Local runner Sarah Miller was the favorite to become the race **champion** this morning. However, halfway through, an old wall began to **collapse** near the track due to a minor earthquake. Sarah stopped running to help an elderly spectator who had suffered a head **injury** from falling debris. She stayed until the **medical** staff arrived. Even though she finished last, the committee awarded her a special **medal** for her bravery. They praised her **dedication** to the community.

What truly defines a professional athlete? Is it the shiny gold **medal** hanging on the wall, or the title of world **champion**? While these are symbols of success, they are merely the results of years of invisible **dedication**. Athletes often push their bodies to the absolute limit, sometimes to the point where their physical systems **collapse** under the pressure. When a career-threatening **injury** occurs, it is not just a physical challenge. Beyond the reach of modern **medical** science, it is the athleteâ€™s inner will that determines if they can return.

Behind the roaring cheers lies a grueling reality. To pursue an Olympic **medal**, one must surrender everything. This level of **dedication** is often romanticized, yet it borders on obsession. We witness elite sprinters whose world-class forms suddenly **collapse** in the final meters, victims of immense physiological strain. Often, a single **injury** is all it takes to derail a decade of preparation, rendering one a former **champion** overnight. While the **medical** interventions available today are sophisticated, they cannot always mend a shattered dream.

My piano concert was a big **success** last night. Before I went on stage, I was so nervous and felt a little **pain** in my stomach. However, I saw you in the crowd and felt your **support**. It gave me the **courage** to play my best. The music was very **emotional**, and some people even cried. After the show, the theater **staff** told me I did a great job.

Nurses often see patients in great physical **pain**, which can be very **emotional** for everyone involved. To keep going, the hospital **staff** need a lot of **courage** and mental strength to face life and death. They also rely on the **support** of their colleagues to get through long, tiring shifts. When a patient finally recovers and goes home, it is considered a wonderful **success** for the entire team.

Many legendary leaders have experienced the **pain** of losing everything before reaching the top. What keeps them moving is often the **emotional** connection they have with their mission. It takes true **courage** to admit when a plan has failed and to try again. Moreover, the **support** from a dedicated team is crucial, as no one can achieve greatness alone. Ultimately, even a small group of **staff** members can change the world. Their grit is the real secret to long-term **success**.

Resilience requires a highly trained **staff** capable of maintaining focus during extreme volatility. When an industry faces a downturn, the psychological **pain** experienced by employees can lead to burnout. Therefore, providing robust **support** systems is a strategic necessity. Leaders must exhibit the professional **courage** to make unpopular decisions for long-term stability. Such high-pressure environments are inevitably **emotional**, yet they serve as the ultimate litmus test for institutional **success**.

Yesterday, Sam saw a cat stuck in a tall tree. The cat began to **struggle** to get down. Sam knew he had to help **immediately**, so he started to climb. He needed all his **strength** to reach the branch. When he finally brought the cat down safely, all the neighbors looked at him with **admiration**. Samâ€™s parents felt great **pride** in their son. Now, everyone in the street gives Sam a lot of **respect**.

From the start, the steep path was a constant **struggle** for my tired legs. I soon realized that I had underestimated the physical **strength** required for this altitude. When a thick fog rolled in, our guide told us to stop **immediately**. As I looked up at the snowy peak, I felt a deep sense of **admiration** for the professional climbers. They certainly deserve our **respect**. Although I didn't reach the top, I still take **pride** in how high I climbed.

Eleanor Vance dedicated her life to the **struggle** for social justice. Whenever she witnessed unfairness, she would react **immediately** by organizing a protest. Her unwavering moral **strength** allowed her to face powerful opponents without fear. Over the decades, she earned the **respect** of world leaders and citizens alike. Today, visitors express their **admiration** for her sacrifices. Her story remains a source of national **pride**.

In moments of crisis, the ego must be set aside so that one can respond **immediately** to the dictates of conscience. This requires a rare form of inner **strength** that is cultivated through years of reflection. We do not grant our **respect** to those who simply succeed, but to those who maintain their integrity while experiencing a deep **struggle**. Such resilience evokes a profound **admiration** that transcends boundaries. Ultimately, a healthy sense of **pride** is born from the knowledge that one has remained upright.

story.text: The pursuit of athletic excellence is a grueling path paved with paradoxical trials. To eventually emerge as a world **champion**, one must possess a level of **dedication** that borders on the ascetic, sacrificing years for the singular hope of an Olympic **medal**. Yet, a sudden, debilitating **injury** can render a lifetime of preparation moot. When the physical framework begins to **collapse** under immense physiological pressure, the presence of an elite **medical** team is indispensable. The **emotional** toll of a failed campaign is often far more corrosive than the visceral **pain** of a torn ligament. In these dark corridors of defeat, the unwavering **support** of a loyal coaching **staff** becomes the only tether to one's former identity. It requires a rare species of **courage** to find the inner **strength** to rise from the ashes. The ensuing **struggle** to reclaim one's status is a psychological quest to regain self-**respect**. One must act **immediately** to prevent cynicism from taking root, replacing despair with a quiet **pride** in the resilience of the soul. Those who navigate this journey evoke a profound **admiration** from the global community, proving that true **success** is an enduring testament to the indomitable heart.

champion.definition: the winner of a sports event or a competition
champion.example: Howard will be crowned the world chess champion after winning the final next Monday.

dedication.definition: the time, effort, and hard work one puts into achieving a certain goal
dedication.example: Doctor Parker shows total dedication to this project. She has spent a lot of time doing detailed studies since she began the project two years ago.

dedicate.definition: to give a lot of your time and effort to a particular activity
dedicate.example: For eighteen months, this author has dedicated himself to writing a book about the snacks available in Taiwanese night markets.

medal.definition: awarded to someone that has won a race or competition
medal.example: Liz dreamed of coming in first in the race and wearing a shiny gold medal around her neck.

injury.definition: physical damage or harm done to one's body
injury.example: After suffering a serious injury in her last race, the cyclist has no chance of becoming a world champion this time.

injure.definition: to harm yourself or somebody else physically
injure.example: Harry badly injured himself at the beach and was taken to the hospital.

success.definition: the fact that someone achieves something very well
success.example: Monica had great success in her work and became a famous singer after years of dedication.

succeed.definition: to achieve something that you have been trying to do
succeed.example: Despite having faced many difficulties, Kevin still succeeded in starting his own company.

successful.definition: achieving your aims or what was intended
successful.example: If you want to be successful in your job, work hard and never give up.

pain.definition: what you feel when you are hurt, injured, or sick
pain.example: Alex experienced a sharp pain in his leg while hiking.

painful.definition: causing you physical or emotional pain
painful.example: Meg's right arm was injured last week and thus she found carrying heavy things a bit painful.

painfully.definition: in a way that causes you physical or emotional pain
painfully.example: In spite of her sore wrist, Mrs. Davis painfully turned the tight handle until the door opened.

immediately.example: I need to leave immediately, or I'll miss my plane.

immediate.example: Upon getting the call, the police took immediate action and quickly arrived at the scene of the crime.

collapse.definition: to fall down, especially when one faints or feels weak
collapse.example: The woman felt dizzy after the seven-hour train journey and suddenly collapsed in the station.

medical.definition: related to the study and treatment of injury
medical.example: Lisa plans to attend medical school and become a doctor in the future.

staff.definition: a group or team of workers or employees
staff.example: The hotel staff greets all guests in a polite way.

courage.definition: the ability to face a difficult situation
courage.example: It takes courage for first-time swimmers to put their heads under the water.

strength.definition: will power or courage under challenging conditions
strength.example: It's important for a player to have enough mental strength to handle the stress during competitions.

strengthen.definition: to make someone or something stronger
strengthen.example: Spending holidays together greatly strengthens the bond between Henry and his family.

support.example: The crowd cheered loudly to show their support for the tennis player every time she won a point.

struggle.definition: to move with difficulty / a hard fight
struggle.example: With a heavy load in back, the truck struggled slowly up the steep hill.

pride.example: Neil took pride in his brother's determination when he saw him complete the marathon.

proud.definition: feeling pleased about something you have done
proud.example: Laura's parents were proud of her excellent score in science class.

emotional.example: Mr. Jones got very emotional and struggled to hold back the tears when his daughter graduated from law school.

emotion.definition: a strong feeling such as love, fear, or anger
emotion.example: Danny is shy, so it's hard for him to express his emotions and let others know how he feels.

admiration.example: Fans showed their admiration for the amazing actor by throwing flowers up onto the stage after the show.

admire.example: Debbie deeply admires Jimmy for his generosity and honesty.

respect.definition: admiration for one's qualities or achievements
respect.example: Mike had great respect for the wise old man and always treated him politely.
